title: 108_hr482
content: The "Florida National Forest Land Management Act of 2003" defines terms like "Secretary" as the Secretary of Agriculture and "State" as the State of Florida. It also addresses the sale or exchange of land. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land parcels in Florida under specified conditions. The described parcels include various tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties, totaling approximately 181.49 acres. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land parcels in Florida, including tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties totaling approximately 181.49 acres. The parcels in Okaloosa County consist of various tracts, such as Mooney Road (0.59 acres), Crestview (79.90 acres), Fairgrounds in Ft. Walton (30.14 acres), City Ball Park in Ft. Walton (12.43 acres), Landfill-Golf Course Driving Range near Crestview (40.85 acres), and 2 vacant lots in Bristol, Liberty County on Micheaux Road. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange Federal land parcels in Florida, including tracts in Santa Rosa and Okaloosa Counties totaling approximately 181.49 acres. Tract A-945 is a Landfill-Golf Course Driving Range in Okaloosa County, approximately 40.85 acres. Tract A-959 consists of 2 vacant lots in Bristol, Liberty County, approximately 0.5 acres. Tract C-3m-d is located southwest of Astor in Lake County, approximately 15.0 acres. Tract C-691 in Lake County includes subsurface rights to approximately 40.76 acres of land. Tracts C-2208b and C-2209 in Lake County consist of approximately 39.99 acres and 127.2 acres respectively. Tracts C-2208b, C-2209, C-2209b, C-2209c, C-2209d, and C-2210 in Lake County, Florida, consist of various acreages and are located in different sections. Tracts C-2209d in Lake County, consisting of approximately 79.58 acres, C-2210 in Marion County, consisting of approximately 30 acres, and C-2213 in Marion County, consisting of approximately 15.0 acres, along with all improvements on the parcels, may have their legal descriptions modified by the Secretary for the purpose of soliciting offers for sale or exchange based on a survey or determination. The Secretary has the authority to modify land descriptions for sale or exchange purposes based on a survey or public interest. Offers for land sale or exchange can be solicited and rejected if deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. The land can be sold publicly or privately, including at auction, with appropriate terms and conditions. The Secretary has the authority to sell land publicly or privately, including at auction, with appropriate terms and conditions. Real estate brokers can be used, and a commission comparable to local rates can be paid. The Secretary of the Air Force must concur on the sale of certain parcels of land. Cash equalization payments can be accepted if the value of non-Federal land is less than the Federal land exchanged. The Secretary of the Air Force may accept cash equalization payments exceeding 25% of the Federal land's value if the non-Federal land's value is lower. Proceeds from land sales or exchanges will be deposited in a specific fund for land acquisition and reimbursement of related costs. The curr_chunk discusses the acquisition of land for the National Forest System in the State and reimbursement of costs incurred by the Secretary for land sales and exchanges. The land acquired under this Act for the National Forest System will be subject to specific laws and regulations, excluding the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949. The land is also withdrawn from public land, mining, and mineral leasing laws, with exceptions for existing rights.
